It's all about finding the weakest link. People think their passwords are so clever, their security questions unbreakable.  They reuse passwords, write them down, fall for phishing scams... amateurs.

Anonymity is the name of the game. You wanna waltz into someone's digital life, grab what you want, and vanish without a trace.

First, forget about using your real name or any personal info online. I use a whole arsenal of burner accounts, disposable emails, and VPNs. Think of it like wearing a mask and gloves, but for the internet.

Tor is my best friend. It bounces my signal all over the place, making it damn near impossible to trace back to me. And I change my IP address more often than I change my socks.

I'm also a master of social engineering. People are the weakest link, you know? A little phishing email, a fake website that looks legit... boom, I'm in. They hand over their passwords like candy.

But the real secret sauce? Compartmentalization. I keep everything separate. One set of tools for recon, another for the attack, and a third for cleaning up my tracks. If one part gets compromised, the others stay safe.

It's a cat-and-mouse game, always staying one step ahead. And trust me, I love the thrill of the chase.
